<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Michael_Strahan skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Michael Strahan</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_NFL_player&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox NFL player (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox NFL player</a>
<b>Michael Anthony Strahan</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>; born November 21, 1971) is a retired <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_football&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American football (page does not exist)">American football</a> <a href="/wiki/Defensive_end" title="Defensive end">defensive end</a> who spent his entire 15-year career playing for the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Giants" title="New York Giants">New York Giants</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a> (NFL). During his tenure with the Giants, Strahan set a record for the most sacks in a single season in 2001, and won a <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLII" title="Super Bowl XLII">Super Bowl</a> in his final season in 2007. After retiring from the NFL, Strahan became a <a href="/wiki/Media_personality" title="Media personality" class="mw-redirect">media personality</a>. He is currently a football analyst on <i><a href="/wiki/Fox_NFL_Sunday" title="Fox NFL Sunday">Fox NFL Sunday</a></i>, and he also serves as co-host on the <a href="/wiki/Television_in_the_United_States" title="Television in the United States">television</a> <a href="/wiki/Breakfast_television" title="Breakfast television">morning</a> <a href="/wiki/Talk_show" title="Talk show">talk show</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Live!_with_Kelly_and_Michael" title="Live! with Kelly and Michael">Live! with Kelly and Michael</a></i> alongside <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kelly_Ripa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kelly Ripa (page does not exist)">Kelly Ripa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> He starred in and produced the short-lived Fox sitcom <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brothers_(2009_TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brothers (2009 TV series) (page does not exist)">Brothers</a></i> and appeared as host for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pros_vs._Joes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pros vs. Joes (page does not exist)">Pros vs. Joes</a></i> alongside fellow Fox football analyst <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jay_Glazer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jay Glazer (page does not exist)">Jay Glazer</a>. On February 1, 2014, he was elected to the <a href="/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame" title="Pro Football Hall of Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#In_the_media"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">In the media</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-10"><a href="#Live.21_with_Kelly_and_Michael_.282012.E2.80.93present.29"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext"><i>Live! with Kelly and Michael</i> (2012&#8211;present)</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-11"><a href="#Personal_life"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Personal life</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#Philanthropy"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Philanthropy</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-14"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<p>Strahan is the son of Gene, a boxer with a 1-1 record against future heavyweight <a href="/wiki/Ken_Norton" title="Ken Norton">Ken Norton</a>, and Louise Strahan, a basketball coach; nephew of retired pro football player Arthur Strahan. He is the youngest of 6 children. Gene was a major in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">U.S. Army</a>, and when Michael was 9, the Strahans moved to an army base in <a href="/wiki/Mannheim" title="Mannheim">Mannheim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>  Although Strahan did not begin to play high school football at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Westbury_High_School_(Houston,_Texas)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Westbury High School (Houston, Texas) (page does not exist)">Westbury High School (Houston, Texas)</a> until his senior year, he did play organized football while attending school in Mannheim, Germany, playing linebacker for the Mannheim Redskins in 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>  The summer before Strahan's senior year of high school, his father sent him to live with his uncle Art in Houston so he could attend <a href="/w/index.php?title=Westbury_High_School_(Houston,_Texas)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Westbury High School (Houston, Texas) (page does not exist)">Westbury High School</a>. Strahan played one season of football, which was enough for him to get a scholarship offer from Texas Southern University. He then flew back to Germany for the spring term, where he graduated from Mannheim Christian Academy.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="College_Career">College Career</span></h2>
<p>Strahan followed in the footsteps of his uncle Art, who also played defensive end at <a href="/wiki/Texas_Southern_University" title="Texas Southern University">Texas Southern University</a>. Strahan was so dominant he drew double teams, and TSU coaches dubbed Strahan double teaming "Strahan rules."<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> By his junior season, Strahan began to turn himself into an NFL prospect.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> As a senior at Texas Southern, Strahan was selected <a href="/wiki/All-America" title="All-America">All-America</a> first team by The Poor Man's Guide to the NFL Draft, The Sheridan Network, Edd Hayes Black College Sports Report and the Associated Press. He recorded 62 tackles with a school-record 19 quarterback sacks and 32 tackles totaling 142 yards in losses. He was also selected Division I-AA Defensive Player of the Year by The Poor Man's Guide and Edd Hayes Black College Sports Report. 
In 1992 he was named 1st team All-Southwestern Athletic Conference and the SWAC's Player of the Year for the 2nd consecutive season. He was also named Black College Defensive Player of the Year. As a junior in 1991, Strahan led the SWAC with 14.5 quarterback sacks. His 41.5 career sacks is a Texas Southern record.<sup id="cite_ref-tsu.edu_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tsu.edu-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_honors">Awards and honors</span></h3>
<ul>
<li> First-team <i>AP</i> College-division All-American (1992)
</li>
<li> Edd Hayes' Black College Sports All-American (1992)
</li>
<li> Inducted into the NFL Hall of Fame (2014)
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Professional_career">Professional career</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_career">Early career</span></h3>
<p>Strahan was drafted in 1993. He played in only 9 games due to injuries, and missed the playoff game that season. After a few unremarkable seasons, Strahan had a breakout year in 1997, recording 14 sacks.  He was voted into his first Pro Bowl and was also named First Team All-Pro by the Associated Press. In 1998, Strahan continued his success, racking up 15 sacks and being voted into his second Pro-Bowl and All-Pro team.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_career">Middle career</span></h3>
<p>Strahan was a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2000_New_York_Giants_season&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2000 New York Giants season (page does not exist)">2000 Giants</a> and participated in their playoff run to <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXV" title="Super Bowl XXXV">Super Bowl XXXV</a>. Despite coming off a strong <a href="/wiki/NFC_Championship_Game" title="NFC Championship Game">NFC Championship Game</a>, where the Giants defeated the <a href="/wiki/Minnesota_Vikings" title="Minnesota Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a> 41&#8211;0, the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens" title="Baltimore Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a> proved too strong for the Giants, who were handily defeated 34&#8211;7 (the most recent Super Bowl to date where a team was held to a touchdown or less).{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In 2002, Michael Strahan and the Giants negotiated on a new contract. He said the team failed to negotiate after he turned down its first contract proposal. He accused the front office of not trying to be competitive in 2002. Four days later, running back <a href="/wiki/Tiki_Barber" title="Tiki Barber">Tiki Barber</a> ripped him for being selfish and greedy. The two had a heated phone conversation that night, and Strahan said they no longer speak. It also surfaced in the spring that the Giants explored trading Strahan, after which he suggested that management had orchestrated the contract flap to make him look bad. The team denied that.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>Few defensive ends in the NFL were more dominant than Strahan from 1997 to 2005. He was named the 2001 NFL Defensive Player of the Year and was a two-time NFC Defensive Player of the Year (in 2001 and 2003). Throughout the greater part of the 2004 season, Strahan was injured with a torn pectoral muscle, which limited him to only 4 sacks. He rebounded in 2005, returning to the Pro Bowl, with his protégé, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Osi_Umenyiora&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Osi Umenyiora (page does not exist)">Osi Umenyiora</a> as the two combined for 26 sacks while anchoring the Giants' defense.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Later_career">Later career</span></h3>
<p>It looked as though Strahan would retire after the 2006 season when he did not report to Giants training camp and missed the entire preseason, but the 14-year veteran opted to return for one final year. On October 23, 2006, with a sack of <a href="/wiki/Drew_Bledsoe" title="Drew Bledsoe">Drew Bledsoe</a> in a Monday night game against the <a href="/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys" title="Dallas Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a>, Strahan tied <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_Taylor" title="Lawrence Taylor">Lawrence Taylor</a> for the Giants franchise record for most career sacks with 132½. It was the last sack Strahan would get that season, as two weeks later he suffered a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lisfranc_fracture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lisfranc fracture (page does not exist)">Lisfranc fracture</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Houston_Texans" title="Houston Texans">Houston Texans</a> and would miss the remainder of the season and the playoffs.
</p><p>His 15th and final season proved to be the Giants' best season since 1990. On September 30, 2007, he sacked <a href="/wiki/Donovan_McNabb" title="Donovan McNabb">Donovan McNabb</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles" title="Philadelphia Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a> on <a href="/w/index.php?title=NBC_Sunday_Night_Football&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NBC Sunday Night Football (page does not exist)">Sunday Night Football</a>, increasing his career total to 133.5, setting a new franchise record. This total does not include 9½ sacks accrued by Taylor in his rookie season of 1981, the year before sacks became an official NFL statistic. On Sunday February 3, 2008, at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Phoenix_Stadium&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Phoenix Stadium (page does not exist)">University of Phoenix Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Glendale,_Arizona" title="Glendale, Arizona">Glendale, Arizona</a>, Strahan had 2 tackles and 1 sack in <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLII" title="Super Bowl XLII">Super Bowl XLII</a>, in what is considered one of the biggest upsets in NFL history.  Bolstered by a strong defense and unrelenting pass rush, the Giants went on to win the game 17-14, over the then-undefeated 18-0 New England Patriots, giving Strahan his first Super Bowl win as an NFL starter. His saying was "Stomp you out!"
</p><p>On June 9, 2008, Michael retired from the <a href="/wiki/NFL" title="NFL" class="mw-redirect">NFL</a>. He told <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jay_Glazer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jay Glazer (page does not exist)">Jay Glazer</a> of Foxsports.com "It's time, I'm done."<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p>Strahan retired with a 2008 Super Bowl Title (his last game), 141.5 career sacks, 854 career <a href="/wiki/Tackle_(football_move)" title="Tackle (football move)">tackles</a>, 4 career <a href="/wiki/Interception" title="Interception">interceptions</a>, 24 <a href="/wiki/Fumble" title="Fumble">forced fumbles</a> and 3 career <a href="/wiki/Touchdown" title="Touchdown">touchdowns</a> in 200 games over a 15 year career (through 2007 season). He was also named to the Pro Bowl roster seven times.
</p><p>On February 2, 2013, Strahan failed to get voted into The <a href="/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame" title="Pro Football Hall of Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>  2013 was his first year of eligibility.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XLVIII&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Super Bowl XLVIII (page does not exist)">Super Bowl XLVIII</a>, played in <a href="/wiki/East_Rutherford,_New_Jersey" title="East Rutherford, New Jersey">East Rutherford, New Jersey</a>, was dedicated to Strahan upon his induction into the <a href="/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame" title="Pro Football Hall of Fame">Pro Football Hall of Fame</a> in <a href="/wiki/2014" title="2014">2014</a>.  Strahan performed the ceremonial <a href="/wiki/Coin_toss" title="Coin toss" class="mw-redirect">coin toss</a>, accompanied by the other members of that year's PBHOF class. Strahan also commentated on the trophy presentation for Fox, since <a href="/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw" title="Terry Bradshaw">Terry Bradshaw</a> (who had commentated on the trophy presentations for Fox's previous Super Bowl broadcasts) was mourning the death of his father.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Strahan.27s_2001_record-breaking_sack">Strahan's 2001 record-breaking sack</span></h3>
<p>In the 2001 season, Strahan set the NFL record for <a href="/wiki/Quarterback_sack" title="Quarterback sack">sacks</a> in a single season with 22.5, the highest tally since it was made an official statistic in 1982; (breaking New York Jets' <a href="/wiki/Mark_Gastineau" title="Mark Gastineau">Mark Gastineau</a>'s total of 22). In the final game of the season, with Strahan coming free, Packers quarterback <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brett_Favre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brett Favre (page does not exist)">Brett Favre</a> slid down and Strahan fell on top of Favre for an easy sack.  After the play, during the ensuing celebration, many of the Giants' defensive players patted Favre on the helmet. At least one observer accused Favre of deliberately falling to ensure that Strahan would get the record.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>  However, Packers right tackle <a href="/wiki/Mark_Tauscher" title="Mark Tauscher">Mark Tauscher</a> claimed it was just a bad play and "we wanted to avoid that sack."<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">New York Times</a></i> columnist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mike_Freeman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mike Freeman (page does not exist)">Mike Freeman</a> wrote, "Yes, Mr. Favre, Strahan deserves the record, but please, handing it to him the way you did, as if you were throwing change into a Salvation Army bucket, is the kind of mistake Favre may never live down."<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_the_media">In the media</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Prose&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Prose (page does not exist)">Template:Prose</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li>An <a href="/w/index.php?title=April_Fools%27_Day&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="April Fools' Day (page does not exist)">April Fools' Day</a> prank (2006) produced an on-screen brawl with <a href="/wiki/Tom_Arnold_(actor)" title="Tom Arnold (actor)">Tom Arnold</a> during an episode of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Best_Damn_Sports_Show_Period" title="The Best Damn Sports Show Period">The Best Damn Sports Show Period</a></i>, in which Strahan allowed Arnold to get the better of him. The two also worked together as judges for the December 7, 2004 contest "America's Craziest Sports Fan" sponsored by MSN.com.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<ul>
<li>During the first half of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2006_NFL_season&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2006 NFL season (page does not exist)">2006 NFL season</a>, Strahan appeared in <a href="/wiki/Pizza_Hut" title="Pizza Hut">Pizza Hut</a> commercials alongside other notable NFL icons.
</li>
<li>Strahan appeared in a long-running commercial for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Right_Guard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Right Guard (page does not exist)">Right Guard</a> antiperspirant in a comedy role where his foul odor made fans pass out.
</li>
<li>Strahan also appeared in a <a href="/wiki/Snickers" title="Snickers">Snickers</a> commercial. In this commercial, a <a href="/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys" title="Dallas Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> fan, with a stereotypical Texan accent, says to Strahan, "Hey! Big ole Michael Strahan, you ain't got nothin'! Let me ask you something: How 'bout them Cowboys?!" Strahan then charges toward the rival fan, who then runs off as the former calls out "You forgot your hat!" A voice-over responds, "Forgetting you're in New York: another unfortunate side-effect of hunger." (An alternate version of this commercial substitutes "impaired judgment" for "forgetting you're in New York".)
</li>
<li>Strahan was the host of the <a href="/wiki/Home_improvement" title="Home improvement">home improvement</a> program <i>Backyard Stadiums</i> on <a href="/w/index.php?title=DIY_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DIY Network (page does not exist)">DIY Network</a>, where he and a team of contractors and gardeners lay out sports courses and goals in <a href="/wiki/Yard_(land)" title="Yard (land)">backyards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>On October 8, 2007, Strahan was a special guest during the opening segment of CNBC's <i><a href="/wiki/Mad_Money" title="Mad Money">Mad Money</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Jim_Cramer" title="Jim Cramer">Jim Cramer</a> and promoted his new book "Inside the Helmet: Life as a Sunday Afternoon Warrior".
</li>
<li>Strahan was featured on the cover of the final video game of the <i><a href="/wiki/NFL_Blitz" title="NFL Blitz">NFL Blitz</a></i> series.
</li>
<li>Strahan made a guest appearance on the second season of the NBC primetime show <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chuck_(TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chuck (TV series) (page does not exist)">Chuck</a></i>.
</li>
<li>On June 24, 2008, it was announced that Strahan would be joining the <i>Fox NFL Sunday</i> pregame show, alongside <a href="/w/index.php?title=Curt_Menefee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Curt Menefee (page does not exist)">Curt Menefee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Terry_Bradshaw" title="Terry Bradshaw">Terry Bradshaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Howie_Long" title="Howie Long">Howie Long</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Johnson_(American_football_coach)" title="Jimmy Johnson (American football coach)">Jimmy Johnson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>In September 2008, Strahan starred in <i>VIP Like Me</i>, a web series for Snickers.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>In March 2009, Strahan reportedly used a <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.lightninggps.com/">Lightning GPS Tracker</a><sup id="cite_ref-LightningGPS_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LightningGPS-16">[16]</a></sup> to keep an eye on his longtime girlfriend without her knowledge. Originally covered by the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nypost.com/seven/03052009/news/regionalnews/love_bug__158077.htm">New York Post</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-New_York_Post_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-New_York_Post-17">[17]</a></sup> this story was later picked up by various news channels.
</li>
<li>Strahan co-starred in the 2009 television <a href="/w/index.php?title=Situation_comedy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Situation comedy (page does not exist)">sitcom</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brothers_(2009_TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brothers (2009 TV series) (page does not exist)">Brothers</a></i> for <a href="/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<ul>
<li>Strahan stars in award winning<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> commercial series for Vaseline Men<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Strahan alongside <a href="/wiki/New_York_Giants" title="New York Giants">New York Giants</a> <a href="/wiki/Defensive_end" title="Defensive end">DE</a> <a href="/wiki/Justin_Tuck" title="Justin Tuck">Justin Tuck</a> also appears in <a href="/wiki/Subway_(restaurant)" title="Subway (restaurant)">Subway</a>'s 5 Dollar Foot Long commercials.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Strahan appeared as a commentator in the April 2010 miniseries <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=America:_The_Story_of_Us&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="America: The Story of Us (page does not exist)">America: The Story of Us</a></i>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<ul>
<li>Strahan did a commercial for CA technologies for their new product Total Defense r12.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>In the behind-the-scenes video of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=NFL_Rush_Zone:_Guardians_of_the_Core&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NFL Rush Zone: Guardians of the Core (page does not exist)">NFL Rush Zone: Guardians of the Core</a></i>, Strahan appears as the last football star in the video.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Live.21_with_Kelly_and_Michael_.282012.E2.80.93present.29"><i>Live! with Kelly and Michael</i> (2012&#8211;present)</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kelly_and_Michael.jpg" title="File:Kelly and Michael.jpg">File:Kelly and Michael.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Logo of the show <i>Live! with Kelly and Michael</i></div></div></div>
<p>On October 1, 2010, Strahan co-hosted <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Live!_with_Regis_and_Kelly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Live! with Regis and Kelly (page does not exist)">Live! with Regis and Kelly</a></i> with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kelly_Ripa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kelly Ripa (page does not exist)">Kelly Ripa</a> for the first time when Regis was absent for that show.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Regis left in November 2011, leaving an empty spot. After twenty guest appearances over two years, Strahan was selected as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kelly_Ripa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kelly Ripa (page does not exist)">Kelly Ripa</a>'s new co-host on September 4, 2012, marking his first official day on the rechristened syndicated talk show, <i><a href="/wiki/Live!_with_Kelly_and_Michael" title="Live! with Kelly and Michael">Live! with Kelly and Michael</a></i>. Ratings instantly surged, impressively generating year-over-year time slot gains across all key demographics. Towering over its nearest competition, the fourth hour of <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Today_(U.S._TV_program)" title="Today (U.S. TV program)">Today Show</a></i>, by 87 percent,<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> Strahan is credited for taking the show "to a whole new level."<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
<p>Strahan resides in <a href="/wiki/Rutherford,_New_Jersey" title="Rutherford, New Jersey">Rutherford, New Jersey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>Strahan was married to his first wife Wanda Hutchins in Germany until 1996.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>  They have a daughter, Tanita (1992), and son Michael Jr. (1995). Strahan then moved them to the US and purchased a $163,000 house in the same <a href="/wiki/Houston" title="Houston">Houston</a> neighborhood in which his parents reside; he pays $2,500 monthly in child support.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1999, he married Jean Muggli of <a href="/wiki/North_Dakota" title="North Dakota">North Dakota</a>.  Stories conflict as to whether they met at a 1996 book signing<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> or at a <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> spa.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>  They have twin daughters, Sophia and Isabella (born October 2004). They divorced acrimoniously in 2006. Jean Muggli accused Strahan of beating her, videotaping her sister, and repeatedly cheating.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> In January 2007 Judge James B Cooney awarded Muggli $15 million in a divorce settlement<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> in addition to $18,000 monthly child support.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>  In her testimony, Muggli claimed that their (at the time 20-month-old) daughters liked "to be accessorized",<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> and that “Isabella doesn't like to leave the house without a purse” and that the children's preferences justified her spending $22,500 on photo shoots, $27,000 on clothing, and $1,700 for <a href="/wiki/Sign_language" title="Sign language">sign language</a> classes. (Neither daughter is hearing impaired.)<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>  With this being more than half of his $22 million in assets, Strahan appealed. In March 2007, divorce judge Cooney ordered the mansion to be auctioned and the sales money split evenly with Jean;<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> the house is valued at $3.6 million.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2011, Strahan filmed a commercial supporting legalizing <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_New_York" title="Same-sex marriage in New York">same-sex marriage in New York</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>Michael Strahan is now engaged to Nicole Mitchell, <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Murphy" title="Eddie Murphy">Eddie Murphy</a>'s ex-wife.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Philanthropy">Philanthropy</span></h2>
<p>In 2002 he had a multimillion dollar restoration and renovation done <sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> on <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jlmn.org/content/mn/Postmark/September2002.pdf">Georgian Heights</a>, a home built in 1906 at 99 Lloyd Ave, a red brick house with a carriage house and greenhouse that he bought in 2000 for $1.3 million.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>  Before moving in he allowed the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jlmn.org">Junior League of Montclair-Newark</a> to use his house as a model home for its Montclair Junior League show house charity fundraiser.<sup id="cite_ref-query.nytimes.com_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-query.nytimes.com-41">[41]</a></sup> From May 28–31 the League decorated the mansion, had a 'bare bones' party and a black-tie affair; they also held $25 tours <sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> to fund Junior League programs called Children At Risk and HomeCorp.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Children At Risk aids children and families <sup id="cite_ref-query.nytimes.com_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-query.nytimes.com-41">[41]</a></sup> and HomeCorp is a housing agency that helps low income people achieve home ownership.
</p><p>"Basically, we're redoing our house to let strangers walk through it for a month," Strahan said. "It's a month-long fundraiser. They'll come in and decorate, paint the walls. They'll hang the curtains, bring in furniture, light fixtures. None of it will be ours. When they're done, if we want something, we get it at cost."
</p><p>In February 2008, Strahan and Giants teammate <a href="/wiki/Justin_Tuck" title="Justin Tuck">Justin Tuck</a> teamed up with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nike,_Inc.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nike, Inc. (page does not exist)">Nike</a> to design their own exclusive pair of sneakers for ID studio in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>. All proceeds of the sneakers were donated to Nike’s <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.letmeplay.com/">Let Me Play</a> global campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-nikeid_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nikeid-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the 2007 arrest of <a href="/wiki/Michael_Vick" title="Michael Vick">Michael Vick</a> on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dogfighting&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dogfighting (page does not exist)">dogfighting</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bad_Newz_Kennels_dog_fighting_investigation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bad Newz Kennels dog fighting investigation (page does not exist)">charges</a>, Strahan appeared in a televised <a href="/wiki/Public_service_announcement" title="Public service announcement">public service announcement</a> for <a href="/wiki/People_for_the_Ethical_Treatment_of_Animals" title="People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals">PETA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>

</p>

	<h3 id="p-namespaces-label">Namespaces</h3>
